elements.content: Five two-dimensional (2D) metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) constructed from Cu(II)-based paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBUs) and 2,4,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (TFBDC) are reported. These compounds exhibit a distorted tetragonal sheet topology with variable pore structures. Both the intralayer and the interlayer cavities of these MOFs can be tailored as either closed, partially open, or fully open with the aid of appropriate guest species. In addition, the nature and dimension of interstitial spaces can be modified using various axial ligands of SBUs. Crystal-to-crystal transformations (CCT) occur among some of these compounds. Such behavior is attributed to the wide range of possible conformations in TFBDC.

elements.content: Five two-dimensional metal−organic frameworks constructed from Cu(II)-based paddle-wheel secondary building units and 2,4,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (TFBDC) are reported. The flexible TFBDC ligands facilitate variable host cavities through induced-fit structural rearrangements.

elements.content: Crystal engineering of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted interest over the past several years as a result of the potential promise these materials have in areas as diverse as gas adsorption, ion exchange, magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and luminescence and nonlinear optics (NLO). Interest in the development of MOFs was at least partially inspired by inorganic zeolite chemistry where silicate-based materials exhibit a remarkable variety of architectures, exceptional propensity to maintain structural integrity even under extreme conditions (such as guest release, ion exchange or high temperatures), and an intriguing capability to selectively bind certain guest species. Nevertheless, MOFs are of particular interest in their own right as they are inherently associated with a number of attractive characteristics, among which are the modularity of their synthesis and controllability of the resulting topologies and dimensions. For example, MOFs with extremely large pores, featuring a surface area more than 5 times as high as that of the best zeolites, have recently been characterized.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted interest over the past several years as a result of the potential promise these materials have in areas as diverse as gas adsorption, ion exchange, magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and luminescence and nonlinear optics (NLO). Interest in the development of MOFs was at least partially inspired by inorganic zeolite chemistry where silicate-based materials exhibit a remarkable variety of architectures, exceptional propensity to maintain structural integrity even under extreme conditions (such as guest release, ion exchange or high temperatures), and an intriguing capability to selectively bind certain guest species. Nevertheless, MOFs are of particular interest in their own right as they are inherently associated with a number of attractive characteristics, among which are the modularity of their synthesis and controllability of the resulting topologies and dimensions. For example, MOFs with extremely large pores, featuring a surface area more than 5 times as high as that of the best zeolites, have recently been characterized.

elements.content: Another feature of MOFs is the dynamic behavior associated with certain families of porous MOFs. Crystalline MOFs have been demonstrated to be able to accommodate “induced-fit” structural transformations upon internal or external stimuli, which include guest release/loading, guest exchange, ligand exchange, light, and chemical reagents. Among these solid-state transformations, three types can be identified, i.e., crystal-to-amorphous transformation (CAT), crystal-to-crystal transformation (CCT), and amorphous-to-crystal transformation (ACT). Whereas ACT is relatively less common and only occurs in rare cases, both CAT and CCT have been frequently observed in a wide variety of porous MOFs. CAT is typically seen in the early examples of MOF structures, or the so-called “first generation compounds”, where release of guest species often leads to framework collapse. CCT represents an intriguing scenario and can be regarded as a unique route for recrystallization, namely, solid-state recrystallization. In particular, single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation (SCSCT), in which rearrangement of MOF structures takes place without loss of their single crystallinity, has recently been of intense interest because it facilitates accurate structural investigation and offers potential for developing functional materials such as devices and sensors. Impressively, a large number of porous MOF compounds involving SCSCT have been reported in the past few years, and an increasing amount of information on structural and binding dynamics of MOFs is now available.

elements.content: The degree of structural rearrangement that flexible MOFs sustain upon internal/external stimuli can vary from being essentially intact14a to exhibiting large framework shrinkage or expansion. Most strikingly, drastic reconstruction of frameworks via coordination bond breaking and re-forming while retaining crystallinity has been observed in a number of cases that are presumably based upon solid-state mechanisms. Reversibility of the solid-state transformation processes is also of relevance, as it is important from a functional material perspective. Indeed, a majority of the reported MOF examples of SCSCT are reversible. Interestingly, in some of these MOF materials, guest-dependent transformations not only alter their supramolecular structures but also significantly influence their physical properties such as magnetism, optical properties, and binding affinity toward other species.

elements.content: We have recently focused upon using paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBUs) M2(RCOO)4 and bifunctional 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) to construct a series of two-dimensional (2D) tetragonal sheets with an undulating nature and containing nanoscale cavities. Paddle-wheel SBUs, in which two metal ions are bridged by four carboxylate anions and each metal is bonded to one axial ligand, can be considered as “molecular squares” when viewed along the axial direction (Figure a). BDC is an angular ligand subtending an angle of 120° and exhibits a relatively small range of carboxyl torsion angles as defined by the dihedral angle between carboxylate plane and phenyl plane (Figures b and a). BDC is thus suitable for the linking of square SBUs to generate more rigid frameworks. To explore MOFs with more dynamic features, however, a higher degree of structural flexibility should be introduced into molecular building blocks as a design element. A Cambridge Structural Database (CSD)22 analysis suggests benzenecarboxylates in general (and BDC in particular) have a narrow range of carboxyl torsion angles, whereas those of the fluorinated counterparts manifest a much wider distribution (Figure ).

elements.content: In this context, a fluorinated version of BDC, namely, 2,4,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (TFBDC; Figure c) has attracted our interest. We herein demonstrate that TFBDC, whose carboxylate groups can adopt a range of torsion angles, can be used to link paddle-wheel square SBUs and afford 2D MOFs related to the prototypal tetragonal sheets that are derived from BDC and the square SBUs. Most intriguingly, the fluorine-substituted metal−organic compounds reported herein contain interesting intralayer pore structures (i.e., cavities within each sheet) that can be tailored as either closed, partially open, or fully open, with the aid of appropriate guest species. A crystal-to-crystal transformation (CCT) has been observed in at least one case. The switch-on/off can be controlled for the interlayer pore structures (i.e., cavities formed by the packing of adjacent sheets) using similar strategies. To our knowledge, such dynamic behavior has not yet been observed in BDC-based metal−organic tetragonal sheets, and the simultaneous presence of two types of manageable cavities is uncommon.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. All reagents were purchased as high purity from Sigma-Aldrich or Fisher Scientific and used without further purification. Solvents were purified according to standard methods and stored in the presence of molecular sieve. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under nitrogen on a TA Instrument TGA 2950 Hi-Res. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Avatar 320 FT-IR spectrophotometer. X-ray powder diffraction (XPD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer at 20 kV, 5 mA for Cuk α (λ = 1.5418 Å), with a scan speed of 0.5 s/step (6°/min) and a step size of 0.05° in 2θ at room temperature. The simulated XPD patterns were produced using Powder Cell for Windows Version 2.4 (programmed by W. Kraus and G. Nolze, BAM Berlin, 2000).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. All reagents were purchased as high purity from Sigma-Aldrich or Fisher Scientific and used without further purification. Solvents were purified according to standard methods and stored in the presence of molecular sieve. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under nitrogen on a TA Instrument TGA 2950 Hi-Res. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Avatar 320 FT-IR spectrophotometer. X-ray powder diffraction (XPD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer at 20 kV, 5 mA for Cuk α (λ = 1.5418 Å), with a scan speed of 0.5 s/step (6°/min) and a step size of 0.05° in 2θ at room temperature. The simulated XPD patterns were produced using Powder Cell for Windows Version 2.4 (programmed by W. Kraus and G. Nolze, BAM Berlin, 2000).

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu 2 (TFBDC) 2 (quinoline)] n (1). Compound 1 was obtained by layering 3.5 mL of an ethanol solution containing 2,4,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (23 mg, 0.10 mmol) and quinoline (0.059 mL, 0.50 mmol) onto 3.5 mL of an ethanol/o-xylene solution (2.5:1, v/v) containing Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (23 mg, 0.10 mmol). Green block crystals formed at the interlayer boundary within 24 h. Yield:  33 mg (38.5%); FTIR (cm-1):  1659 (m), 1637 (s) 1596 (w), 1509 (m), 1487 (m), 1381 (s), 1317 (w), 1242 (w), 1132 (w), 1100 (m), 1053 (w), 970 (s), 819 (m), 794 (s), 786 (s), 742 (w), 698 (s), 663 (w), 626 (m), 607 (m).

elements.content: Crystal Structure Determination. Single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis were selected following examination under a microscope. Intensity data were collected on a Bruker-AXS SMART APEX/CCD diffractometer using Mok α radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and for absorption using the SADABS program. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on |F|2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions and refined with temperature factors 1.2 times those of their bonded atoms (the sp3 methyl hydrogens in compounds 4 and 5 were refined with temperature factors 1.5 times those of their bonded atoms). All crystallographic calculations were conducted with the SHELXTL 5.1 program package. Table provides crystallographic data for compounds 1−5. Atomic coordinates and thermal parameters have been deposited, and the CCDC numbers are given in Table . These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Rd., Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax:  (+44)1223−3363-033; or deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Design Principles. Unlike inorganic zeolites, whose frameworks are based upon rigid single atoms (such as Si and O) and their strong covalent linkages, the basic building units (e.g., organic ligands and inorganic clusters) in MOF structures are molecular in nature and they may adopt various dimensions and shapes. In addition, the supramolecular interactions present in MOFs, such as metal−ligand interactions, hydrogen bonds, and π−π stacks, are in general energetically weaker and dynamically more flexible compared to covalent bonds. In principle, two different approaches can be applied in this context:  (i) use of weak linkages and (ii) use of flexible components. Kitagawa et al. has systematically explored the first strategy in an effort to construct dynamic functional materials. Our CSD analysis on ligand conformations (Figure ) indicates that introducing fluorine atoms into the ligand systems can be effectively used to realize the second approach, as carboxyl groups in fluorinated ligands tend to assume a higher degree of torsional diversity (with respect to the phenyl rings). As will be detailed below, the calixarene-like nanoscale SBUs (nSBUs)21 composed of four paddle-wheel units and four BDC moieties can be transformed into doubly edged axe-shaped motifs that are capable of shrinking or expanding, depending upon the presence of various guests (Figure ). On the other hand, the near-planar conformation of unsubstituted BDC ligands precludes the formation of such diversity in the pore structures.

Results and Discussion

 Design Principles. Unlike inorganic zeolites, whose frameworks are based upon rigid single atoms (such as Si and O) and their strong covalent linkages, the basic building units (e.g., organic ligands and inorganic clusters) in MOF structures are molecular in nature and they may adopt various dimensions and shapes. In addition, the supramolecular interactions present in MOFs, such as metal-ligand interactions, hydrogen bonds, and π-π stacks, are in general energetically weaker and dynamically more flexible compared to covalent bonds. In principle, two different approaches can be applied in this context: (i) use of weak linkages and (ii) use of flexible components. Kitagawa et al. has systematically explored the first strategy in an effort to construct dynamic functional materials. Our CSD analysis on ligand conformations (Figure ) indicates that introducing fluorine atoms into the ligand systems can be effectively used to realize the second approach, as carboxyl groups in fluorinated ligands tend to assume a higher degree of torsional diversity (with respect to the phenyl rings). As will be detailed below, the calixarene-like nanoscale SBUs (nSBUs)21 composed of four paddle-wheel units and four BDC moieties can be transformed into doubly edged axe-shaped motifs that are capable of shrinking or expanding, depending upon the presence of various guests (Figure ). On the other hand, the near-planar conformation of unsubstituted BDC ligands precludes the formation of such diversity in the pore structures.

elements.content: Crystal Structures of 2D MOFs. [Cu 2 (TFBDC) 2 (quinoline)] n (1). Compound 1 was harvested as green single crystals from an ethanol solution of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O and TFBDC using quinoline as the base and relatively bulky aromatic molecules (such as o-xylene) as crystallization templates. Figure a reveals a contracted 2D tetragonal sheet topology that is sustained by Cu(II)-based paddle-wheel square SBUs and TFBDC moieties. Only one type of crystallographically independent SBU and TFBDC ligand exists; however, there are two carboxylate torsion angles in each TFBDC (see below for details). The Cu−Cu distance in each SBU is ca. 2.76 Å, consistent with the average value seen in this type of motif. Within each 2D sheet, the fluorinated rings of two opposite TFBDC ligands face each other with a short centroid−centroid distance (3.67 Å), an indication of π−π interactions. Such a short contact effectively closes off the free space that may otherwise be available to guest species. Notably, the axial quinolines also participate in C−H···π interactions with other quinoline ligands and the D value (distance from C to the aromatic ring) is ca. 3.68 Å within each layer and ca. 3.76 Å between adjacent layers, respectively. As a result of such efficient close-packing, there are no interstitial spaces, and 1 can thus be described as an “apohost” framework (a host framework without guest molecules).

elements.content: {[Cu 2 (TFBDC) 2 (quinoline) 2 ]·( o -dichlorobenzene) 0.5 } n (2). Compound 2 was obtained from a reaction mixture of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O, TFBDC, quinoline, and o-dichlorobenzene in ethanol solution. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction indicates that 2 retains a similar overall 2D architecture to that of 1, i.e., a distorted tetragonal sheet (Figure ). In contrast to 1, however, two crystallographically independent square SBUs exist, and the Cu−Cu distances are ca. 2.74 and 2.75 Å, respectively. There are also two types of TFBDC ligands and hence four different carboxylate torsion angles. In addition, o-dichlorobenzene guest molecules are found in the crystal structure of 2 and presumably play an essential role in opening the intralayer cavities that are each defined by four SBUs and four TFDBC moieties. Interestingly, o-dichlorobenzene occupies only half of these cavities, leaving the other half closed. Such occupancy leads to two distinct dimensions for the open and closed cavities, and the centroid−centroid distances between opposite TFBDC rings vary by more than 2.40 Å (6.79 vs 4.39 Å). Within the open cavities, crystallographically disordered o-dichlorobenzene molecules are sandwiched by two TFBDCs, and the centroid−centroid distance from o-dichlorobenzene to each of the TFBDC rings is 3.40 Å, indicating parallel π−π interactions between these aromatic systems. It is perhaps of interest to compare the centroid−centroid distances of the closed cavities in 2 (4.39 Å) with those in 1 (3.67 Å). Such a discrepancy can presumably be attributed to the structural distortion of 2, which is induced by the presence of o-dichlorobenzene.

elements.content: The structural deformations caused by guest molecules o-dichlorobenzene are further evidenced by the subtle changes of intralayer and interlayer interactions among quinoline ligands. Whereas quinolines within each layer still participate in C−H···π interactions (D = 3.79 Å), only half as many interactions occur because of a much larger separation for the other half (D = 7.11 Å) that is caused by the expansion of the open cavities. The interlayer interactions between quinolines, on the other hand, manifest both π···π (d centroid−centroid = 3.36 and 3.34 Å) and C−H···π bonding (D = 3.77 Å) in contrast to the appearance of only C−H···π interactions in 1.

Whereas quinolines within each layer still participate in C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions (D = 3.79 Å), only half as many interactions occur because of a much larger separation for the other half (D = 7.11 Å) that is caused by the expansion of the open cavities. The interlayer interactions between quinolines, on the other hand, manifest both π⋅⋅⋅π (d centroid-centroid = 3.36 and 3.34 Å) and C-H⋅⋅⋅π bonding (D = 3.77 Å) in contrast to the appearance of only C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions in 1.

elements.content: {[Cu 2 (TFBDC) 2 (quinoline) 2 ]·(chlorobenzene) 0.5 } n (3). A third compound, 3, was isolated as a single-crystalline product when chlorobenzene is used in place of o-dichlorobenzene. 3 also exhibits a 2D distorted tetragonal sheet topology with a network composition identical to that of 1 and 2. Also similar to 2, there are two crystallographically independent sets of SBUs (Cu−Cu distances:  ca. 2.75 Å) and TFBDCs (with four varied carboxylate torsion angles). As illustrated in Figure a, the 2D framework displays a closed mode with two types of short contacts between opposite TFBDC rings (d centroid - centroid = 4.15 and 4.65 Å, respectively), suggesting effective π···π interactions. Quinolines again play an important role in stabilizing each of the 2D layers by engaging in an array of C−H···π interactions (D = 3.98 Å). Surprisingly, instead of occupying the intralayer space as seen in 2, chlorobenzene is found to be hosted by the interlayer cavities that are enclosed by quinolines on the sides and TFBDCs from the top and bottom (Figure c). While these cavities are mainly constructed from quinolines which engage in alternate π···π (d centroid - centroid = 3.93 Å) and C−H···π interactions (D = 3.58 and 3.98 Å), the entrapped chlorobenzene molecules are sandwiched by TFBDC rings from adjacent layers through 2-fold π···π interactions (d centroid - centroid = 4.00 Å). However, only half of these interlayer cavities are occupied by chlorobenzene molecules, and the other half remain guest-free (Figure d), resembling the host−guest interactions in 2. Calculations25 suggest a volume of ca. 130 Å3 for the first type of cavities, in good accordance with the molecular volume of chlorobenzene (98.5 Å3), and a near-zero volume for the second type of cavities. The alternate occupancy of the interlayer cavities by chlorobenzene also accounts for two different centroid−centroid distances observed within each layer in 3 (4.65 vs 4.15 Å; the former belongs to the ones involved with chlorobenzene) since the interactions between the TFBDC rings and the sandwiched chlorobenzene molecules drive the TFBDC rings slightly away from their opposite partners from the same layer with which they are simultaneously interacting.

elements.content: {[Cu 2 (TFBDC) 2 (EtOH) 2 ]·(EtOH) 2 ·(benzene)} n (4). Blue-green crystals of 4 were prepared from ethanol containing Cu(NO3)2·6H2O, TFBDC, benzene, and 2,6-lutidine. Structural analysis based on X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals the familiar 2D distorted tetragonal sheet with one type of crystallographically independent SBU (Cu−Cu distance:  2.66 Å) and two types of TFBDCs (four different carboxylate torsion angles). Unlike 2, for which only half of the intralayer cavities are filled with o-dichlorobenzene, each of the doubly edged axe-shaped cavities in 4 is occupied by one benzene molecule that interacts with TFBDC rings through π···π stacking (Figure a; d centroid - centroid = 3.48 and 3.54 Å). Such a variance can presumably be attributed to the different sizes of the guest molecules. The weak coordination ability of 2,6-lutidine means that solvent molecules (ethanol) coordinate at the axial positions of SBUs, thus modifying both the steric and the electronic environments on the exterior of the 2D networks. The interlayer cavities are therefore more hydrophilic, and two ethanol molecules (instead of benzene) sit as guests inside each of them. Interestingly, these ethanol guests hydrogen bond to the frameworks in two distinct motifs, one of which involves only the coordinated EtOH, while the other takes advantage of both coordinated ethanol and carboxyl oxygens (Figure c). Four different hydrogen-bond distances (d o···o = 2.61, 2.82, 2.63, and 2.98 Å) are within the anticipated range for this type of interactions.

elements.content: {[Cu 2 (TFBDC) 2 (2-picoline) 2 ](EtOH) 1.3 (HFB)} ∞ (5). When 2-picoline was used in place of quinoline or 2,6-lutidine, and hexafluorobenzene (HFB) was used as the crystallization template, another doubly edged axe-shaped 2D tetragonal sheet, 5, was obtained (Figure ). There is only one type of crystallographically independent SBU (Cu−Cu distance:  2.76 Å), but there are two different types of TFBDCs and four different carboxylate torsion angles. Similar to 1 and 3, the intralayer cavities are in the off mode, and the centroid−centroid distance between opposite TFBDC rings within each layer is 4.28 Å, in good agreement with those of 3 (d centroid - centroid = 4.15 Å and 4.65 Å) but slightly larger than those of 1 ( d centroid - centroid = 3.665 Å). The ligand 2-picoline, which is smaller than quinoline, affords larger interlayer cavities in which HFB and disordered ethanol molecules coexist as guest species. There are two distinct 2-picoline ligands, one of which is crystallographically disordered over two positions. Each interlayer cavity is defined by two disordered and four ordered 2-picoline molecules from adjacent layers on the sides and TFBDC moieties on the top and bottom (Figure c). Interestingly, pairs of ordered 2-picoline molecules associate with each other via face-to-face π···π interactions (d centroid - centroid = 3.64 Å), whereas the disordered ones sandwich HFB molecules in a similar fashion (d centroid - centroid = 3.63 Å).

elements.content: Solid -State Transformations in 1 − 3. The frameworks of compounds 1−3 are constructed from identical building blocks, i.e., Cu(II)-based paddle-wheel SBU, TFBDC, and quinoline. Although these structures were prepared separately from solution, it was of interest to us to explore their inter-relationships in solid state. Therefore, X-ray powder diffraction (XPD) and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed on these solids to characterize their susceptibility to phase changes. The XPDs we obtained suggest that the as-synthesized samples of 1 are stable at room temperature, and TGA confirms the absence of any guest molecules, which is consistent with the single-crystal structure (Figures and ). The framework starts to decompose at ca. 210 °C, possibly induced by the loss of quinoline ligands. Notably, both XPD and TGA give almost identical results for the as-synthesized samples of 2 (typically handled within 5−10 min after removal from the mother liquor) as in the case of 1, strongly suggesting that 2 undergoes a crystal-to-crystal transformation (CCT) and converts to 1 upon loss of o-dichlorobenzene guests. It should be noted that multiple single crystals from various batches under the same reaction recipe have been examined on the X-ray diffraction instrument, and they unequivocally give the same result, i.e., a host−guest complex 2. It is therefore reasonable to assume that single crystals of 2 indeed represent the major bulk sample in the original vial and they remain stable under the experimental conditions in which single-crystal diffraction data are collected. It is nevertheless somewhat surprising to us how unstable the complexation between TFBDC and o-dichlorobenzene appears in light of their short contacts. Compound 3, on the hand, appears to be much more robust at ambient conditions, and the loss of chlorobenzene only occurs at temperatures higher than 160 °C. Although we are not able to determine the structure of the apohost of 3 at this point, it is likely that a new phase other than 1 is generated as a result of losing chlorobenzene from the interlayer cavities, as this unknown intermediate exhibits a different decomposition temperature (ca. 250 vs 210 °C; Figure c). Finally, numerous attempts to incorporate chlorobenzene/o-dichlorobenzene into the framework of 1 under various conditions (including heating 1 in large excess amounts of either liquid) have been unsuccessful.

Although these structures were prepared separately from solution, it was of interest to us to explore their inter-relationships in solid state. Therefore, X-ray powder diffraction (XPD) and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed on these solids to characterize their susceptibility to phase changes. The XPDs we obtained suggest that the as-synthesized samples of 1 are stable at room temperature, and TGA confirms the absence of any guest molecules, which is consistent with the single-crystal structure (Figures  and ). The framework starts to decompose at ca. 210 °C, possibly induced by the loss of quinoline ligands. Notably, both XPD and TGA give almost identical results for the as-synthesized samples of 2 (typically handled within 5-10 min after removal from the mother liquor) as in the case of 1, strongly suggesting that 2 undergoes a crystal-to-crystal transformation (CCT) and converts to 1 upon loss of o-dichlorobenzene guests. It should be noted that multiple single crystals from various batches under the same reaction recipe have been examined on the X-ray diffraction instrument, and they unequivocally give the same result, i.e., a host-guest complex 2. It is therefore reasonable to assume that single crystals of 2 indeed represent the major bulk sample in the original vial and they remain stable under the experimental conditions in which single-crystal diffraction data are collected. It is nevertheless somewhat surprising to us how unstable the complexation between TFBDC and o-dichlorobenzene appears in light of their short contacts. Compound 3, on the hand, appears to be much more robust at ambient conditions, and the loss of chlorobenzene only occurs at temperatures higher than 160 °C. Although we are not able to determine the structure of the apohost of 3 at this point, it is likely that a new phase other than 1 is generated as a result of losing chlorobenzene from the interlayer cavities, as this unknown intermediate exhibits a different decomposition temperature (ca. 250 vs 210 °C; Figure c). Finally, numerous attempts to incorporate chlorobenzene/o-dichlorobenzene into the framework of 1 under various conditions (including heating 1 in large excess amounts of either liquid) have been unsuccessful.

elements.content: Dynamic Pore Structures in 1 − 5. Compounds 1−5 exhibit two types of dynamic and responsive pore structures within the same 2D metal−organic framework. By simply varying the size and chemical nature of template molecules, intralayer and interlayer cavities are varied. For example, in the case of 1, xylene molecules are sterically excluded from the framework, and as a result a closely packed MOF with no open cavities is formed. When templates such as o-dichlorobenzene or chlorobenzene are used, structures with partially open intra- or interlayer cavities can be obtained. The exclusive closing or opening of either type of pore architectures is also likely to be a reflection of size variations between these two templates. In the case of 4, both the size and the electronic properties of benzene molecules render the possibility of fully occupying the intralayer cavities. On the contrary, in 5, HFB, which is similar to benzene in terms of size, is electronically less compatible with TFBDC and is therefore surrounded by 2-picoline and included between layers.
elements.clean_text: Dynamic Pore Structures in 1 - 5. Compounds 1-5 exhibit two types of dynamic and responsive pore structures within the same 2D metal-organic framework. By simply varying the size and chemical nature of template molecules, intralayer and interlayer cavities are varied. For example, in the case of 1,  xylene molecules are sterically excluded from the framework, and as a result a closely packed MOF with no open cavities is formed. When templates such as o-dichlorobenzene or chlorobenzene are used, structures with partially open intra- or interlayer cavities can be obtained. The exclusive closing or opening of either type of pore architectures is also likely to be a reflection of size variations between these two templates. In the case of 4, both the size and the electronic properties of benzene molecules render the possibility of fully occupying the intralayer cavities. On the contrary, in 5, HFB, which is similar to benzene in terms of size, is electronically less compatible with TFBDC and is therefore surrounded by 2-picoline and included between layers.

elements.content: The key approach we demonstrate herein is to take advantage of the ability of flexible ligands to adapt induced-fit structural rearrangements. As substantiated by the analysis on carboxyl torsion angles in various TFBDC-based structures (Table ), TFBDC is highly flexible on a molecular level and thus ideally suitable for the construction of dynamic MOF materials. Indeed, from a structural perspective, it is the very presence of a wide variety of ligand conformations that accounts for the remarkable structure diversity and dynamic pore structures seen in 1−5. In particular, the high degree of free rotation for the carboxylate groups in TFBDC presumably facilitates the CCT process from 2 to 1 under such mild conditions.

In particular, the high degree of free rotation for the carboxylate groups in TFBDC presumably facilitates the CCT process from 2 to 1 under such mild conditions.

Dynamic metal−organic compounds with induced-fit pore architectures represent an intriguing target in the assembly of functional materials such as sensors and devices. In this context, a compelling design strategy, which utilizes fluorinated ligands to introduce structural flexibility, has been delineated in this study. A series of 2D MOFs with a distorted tetragonal sheet topology are constructed from the combination of rigid and flexible molecular components, namely, Cu(II)-based paddle-wheel SBUs and tetrafluoro-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (TFBDC), respectively. The characteristics of this approach are clear from at least the following perspectives:  (i) the superstructural diversity1c and binding dynamics of MOFs are inherently dictated by the structural variations of flexible molecular building units (e.g., TFBDC), which is, in many aspects, easier to manipulate than the weak-linkage approach; (ii) the coexistence of two types of guest-dependent cavities in the same MOF offers the possibility of generating functional materials that can simultaneously recognize multiple guest species at different “recognition pockets”; (iii) the design principle is in principle generic since other types of ligand systems (or inorganic units) incorporated with flexible structural elements can also be effectively applied. Although the robustness and reversibility of our present MOF system need to be improved from practical considerations, the approach we describe herein could facilitate the development of functional materials with fine-tunable pores.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Dynamic metal-organic compounds with induced-fit pore architectures represent an intriguing target in the assembly of functional materials such as sensors and devices. In this context, a compelling design strategy, which utilizes fluorinated ligands to introduce structural flexibility, has been delineated in this study. A series of 2D MOFs with a distorted tetragonal sheet topology are constructed from the combination of rigid and flexible molecular components, namely, Cu(II)-based paddle-wheel SBUs and tetrafluoro-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (TFBDC),  respectively. The characteristics of this approach are clear from at least the following perspectives: (i) the superstructural diversity1c and binding dynamics of MOFs are inherently dictated by the structural variations of flexible molecular building units (e.g., TFBDC), which is, in many aspects, easier to manipulate than the weak-linkage approach; (ii) the coexistence of two types of guest-dependent cavities in the same MOF offers the possibility of generating functional materials that can simultaneously recognize multiple guest species at different "recognition pockets"; (iii) the design principle is in principle generic since other types of ligand systems (or inorganic units) incorporated with flexible structural elements can also be effectively applied. Although the robustness and reversibility of our present MOF system need to be improved from practical considerations, the approach we describe herein could facilitate the development of functional materials with fine-tunable pores.

Synthesis of [Cu 2 (TFBDC) 2 (quinoline)] n (1). Compound 1 was obtained by layering 3.5 mL of an ethanol solution containing 2,4,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (23 mg, 0.10 mmol) and quinoline (0.059 mL, 0.50 mmol) onto 3.5 mL of an ethanol/o-xylene solution (2.5:1, v/v) containing Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (23 mg, 0.10 mmol).
